organization.$: International Postgraduate Programs in Environmental Management
Center of Excellence for Environmental and Hazardous Waste Management (EHWM)

head.citation-title: Study of cutting oily wastewater treatment by coupling dissolved air flotation (DAF) and coagulation-flocculation processes
head.abstracts: The effects of operating and hydrodynamic conditions on separation of cutting-oil emulsion by coupling processes of dissolved air flotation (DAF) and coagulation-flocculation were studied. The parameters studied were the influent concentration and air flowrate (Qg). The number of air-bubble, which related with the interfacial area (a), played a significant role on the separation efficiency. Increasing the Qg also provided turbulence in the system, which was represented by velocity gradient (G). The optimal G value could result in higher uniformity of bubble sizes, thus providing the advantage to the process. The ratio of bubble's a/G ratio was then proposed as the key factor for appropriate design and operation of DAF process. This ratio considered both effects from bubble's surface area and turbulence, which were expected as critical parameters in the process. The higher a/G ratio, which can be defined as the operating condition with large interfacial area and low turbulence, provided higher separation efficiency. By operating the continuous process, this ratio could be proven as the recommended condition as well as the effects of the important parameters. Thus, this ratio should be applied to propose the optimal operating conditions and design the DAF process for treating the stabilized oily-wastewater. This is an abstract of a paper presented at the CHISA 2012 - 20th International Congress of Chemical and Process Engineering and PRES 2012 - 15th Conference on Process Integration, Modelling and Optimisation for Energy Saving and Pollution Reduction (Prague, Czech Republic 8/25-29/2012).
